Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Effects of perinatal nutrition on the development of central vagal neurocircuits
Award.AbstractNarration: Although it is known that obesity results from a combination of both genetic and environmental causes, it is now becoming apparent that the perinatal period (i.e., pregnancy and the period immediately following birth) is crucial in the development of the brain regions responsible for the control of food intake. By using electrophysiological recording techniques to study the properties and behavior of nerve cells in brain regions associated with the regulation of feeding, this project will investigate the concept that exposure to a diet high in fat during the critical perinatal period permanently alters the properties of neurons in these brain regions, making them less responsive to signals that would normally terminate feeding. The results of these studies will help explain how nutrition affects the development of particular brain regions and may provide a means by which we can understand how the perinatal environment affects the likelihood of developing obesity later in life. This project will also allow graduate students at Penn State College of Medicine to learn a wide variety of different experimental techniques, particularly complex electrophysiological investigations into nerve cell behavior, to answer the far-reaching questions being asked.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Obesity is a multifactorail disease involving both genetic and environmental factors. It has been known for a long time, from both human and animal studies, that the perinatal period (pregnancy and lactation) is critically important in determining lifelong outcomes. Overnutrition during this period is known to increasing the propensity for offspring to develop metabolic syndrome and obesity in later life. This period of time also corresponds to the interval during which the autonomic neurons and neurocircuits that control food intake and energy balance develop. The overall hypothesis of the proposal was that exposure to a high fat diet during the perinatal period alters the development of brainstem neurocircuits regulating gastric functions, including food intake and early satiety.

The project specifically investigated three major aims:

1) the effects of a perinatal high fat diet on the number and neurochemcial properties of enteric neurons in the upper gastrointestinal tract. Previous studies have shown that obeisty causes a loss of myenteric neurons regulating gastrointestinal motility but it is unclear whether these effects are due to diet exposure itself, or to obesity itself. This study investigated the effects of perinatal high fat diet on myenteric neurons prior to the development of obesity and showed that myenteric neurons, particularly inhibitory nitrergic neurons, are lost long before obesity develops, suggesting that diet alone can have serious adverse effects. These changes were accompanied by an increase in glial cells but were not accompanied by alterations in inflammatory markers. 

2) the effects of a perinatal high fat diet on the properties of brainstem neurons innervating the upper gastrointestinal tract. This study used whole cell patch clamp recordings on identifed gastric projecting dorsal motor nuceus of the vagus (DMV) neurons, and showed that DMV neurons were less excitable both due to changes in their intrinsic membrane properties as well as increased inhibitory synaptic inputs. 

3) the effects of a perinatal high fat diet on the development of central vagal neurocircuits. Our studies suggested that exposure to a high fat diet during the perinatal period may alter the normal development of central brainstem neurocircuits, causing the increased inhibitory synaptic transmission observed in adulthood. This necessitated a time-course study to understand the normal development of central brainstem neurocircuits in order to determine the alterations a perinatal high fat diet may exert. This study showed that glycine transmission is common in the first 10-15 postnatal days but declines thereafter, such that adult vagal motoneurons receive only GABA inhibitory inputs. Our studies also suggest that, following a perintal high fat diet, glycine remains as a neurotransmitter, and does not undergo its normal developmental loss such that, in adulthood, both glycine and GABA are used as inhibitory neurotransmitters, contributing to the observed increased synaptic inhibitirion of these neurons. 

This proposal resulted in the publication of 5 manuscripts (PMID 23459752; 25556801; 27440241; 28762595; 29368945) and 4 review articles (27302177; 27988382; 25428846) in peer-reviewed manuscripts with 2 further manuscripts under review and in preparation

This work was also disseminated in the form of two podcasts: 

https://jneurophysiol.podbean.com/e/development-of-inhibitory-transmission-in-central-circuits/

https://itunes.apple.com/gb/podcast/neurogastroenterology-motility-january-2018/id1321324295 Youtube: https://youtu.be/nnOpG-ijYD8

Work from this proposal was also highlighted in other publications:

http://www.alnmag.com/news/2015/04/mothers-diet-influences-weight-control-neurocircuits-offspring

http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2015/03/150330082528.htm

 

The major Broader Impact goal of this proposal was to develop an advanced graduate course in neuroscience, particularly neurophysiology, techniques. This course introduces graduate students to a variety of advanced neuroscience techniques using a combination of didactic lectures, team-based learning and laboratory-based practical experimentation. This graduate course (Neuro 522; Advanced Neuroscience Techniques) is offered to graduate students every other year and has been taught to approximately 18 graduate students (spring 2015 and 2017).with the course currently being modified to fit assessed needs in spring 2019.

As a further goal, this proposal also allowed graduate students, as well as summer undergraduate students, to learn and have hands-on practice with a variety of experimental techniques in short, appropriately oriented, hypothesis drive research experience. This proposal directly supported the thesis projects of three PhD graduate students and 1 Masters students, three of whom have already graduated.
